awd_titl_txt: Algebraic Structures and the Arithmetic of Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Certain types of highly symmetric algebraic structures, such as quadratic forms and division algebras, have been ubiquitous in mathematics and its applications, playing important roles in such diverse fields as multiple-antenna wireless communications, efficient representations of spatial rotations, gauge symmetries of theoretical physics, and Galois representations in number theory. While our understanding of these structures has become quite rich, many fundamental questions still remain. This project will employ and develop new tools from the rapidly growing field of arithmetic geometry to deepen our understanding of these algebraic structures. The principal investigator will be involved in the training of students and the organization of conferences in the field.

This research project will study the interplay between torsors for linear algebraic groups and field arithmetic, with the aim of developing refined versions of period-index type problems for the Brauer group and related notions for other classes of algebraic structures.  Doing this will also involve extending both the scope and applicability of "field patching" and related methods, building on prior work of the investigator with collaborators to produce new local-global principles for wider classes of objects as well as for more general fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this NSF grant was to provide research support for the Principal Investigator (PI) and graduate students, as well as travel funding to facilitate collaborations with other researchers in the field. The goal was to advance our understanding of linear algebraic structures and field arithmetic, including the study of linear algebraic group and their torsors, Galois cohomology, division algebras and quadratic forms. 

During the grant period, the PI and collaborators made significantprogress along these lines, including significantly refinements to local-global principles for semiglobal fields, bounds for symbol length in Galois cohomology and new results concerning the parametrization and specialization of division algebras and other algebraic structures.

In addition to this, connections with mathematical physics emerged leading to new collaborative research in conformal field theory and vertex operator algebras.


This NSF grant supported the completion of approximately 12 papers and played a crucial role in supporting the researchdevelopment and mentoring of 5 graduate students affiliated with the PI, two of whom successfully completed their graduate studies during the award period.


The travel support provided by the grant facilitated collaborationsbetween the PI's group and other researchers in the field, bringing in collaborators from a range of international and domestic universities, and also supported graduate travel to attend professional meetings.
